articles.headline: Calmly, Pick for Treasury Offers Replies to Senators
articles.snippet: Jacob J. Lew, President Obama’s pick to lead the Treasury Department, faced questions about his approach and his work on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Jacob J. Lew, President Obama’s pick to lead the Treasury Department, faced questions about his approach and his work on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jacob J. Lew, President Obama’s nominee for Treasury secretary, faced some fierce questioning on Wednesday from the Senate Finance Committee on his tenure at the bailed-out Citigroup and on an investment based in the Cayman Islands. But the even-tempered, bookish Mr. Lew parried the blows and appeared likely to win the committee’s approval and Senate confirmation.

articles.headline: Blogging With Video, Hoping to Go Viral
articles.snippet: The first rule for would-be video bloggers: Don’t let your ego get between the camera and the audience.
articles.abstract: The first rule for would-be video bloggers: Don’t let your ego get between the camera and the audience.
articles.lead_paragraph: It would take 72 hours to watch all the videos uploaded to YouTube every minute by would-be commentators, comedians, cosmetologists and various other content creators all hoping for a breakout hit.

articles.headline: Brooklynite Hits France, With Plans to Seduce
articles.snippet: Brooklyn Brewery’s strategy is to start small and offer its specialty beers in carefully chosen outlets in the wine-loving country.
articles.abstract: Brooklyn Brewery’s strategy is to start small and offer its specialty beers in carefully chosen outlets in the wine-loving country.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Garrett Oliver popped the cork of one of his specialty brews, swirled the amber liquid into a wine glass and took a hearty sniff.

articles.headline: Time Warner Considers Spinning Off Some of Its Magazines
articles.snippet: Early discussions involve putting most of its titles — but not Time, Fortune or Sports Illustrated — into a separate company with Meredith magazines.
articles.abstract: Early discussions involve putting most of its titles — but not Time, Fortune or Sports Illustrated — into a separate company with Meredith magazines.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Small Businesses Still Struggle, and That’s Impeding a Recovery
articles.snippet: Loans are still tight, consumers are timid, and the action — or lack of it — in Washington has heightened pessimism among small-business owners.
articles.abstract: Loans are still tight, consumers are timid, and the action — or lack of it — in Washington has heightened pessimism among small-business owners.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the recovery so far, small businesses have largely been left behind. Initially, loans were hard to come by and consumers weren’t shopping. Now, small-business owners say, Washington is throwing up additional roadblocks.

articles.headline: American and US Airways Announce Deal for $11 Billion Merger
articles.snippet: The combination – if approved by regulators, bankruptcy court and shareholders – would create the nation’s largest airline.
articles.abstract: The combination – if approved by regulators, bankruptcy court and shareholders – would create the nation’s largest airline.

articles.headline: In High-Tech Japan, the Fax Machines Roll On
articles.snippet: The reluctance to give up fax machines offers a revealing glimpse into an aging nation that can often seem quietly determined to stick to its tried-and-true ways.
articles.abstract: The reluctance to give up fax machines offers a revealing glimpse into an aging nation that can often seem quietly determined to stick to its tried-and-true ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan is renowned for its robots and bullet trains, and has some of the world’s fastest broadband networks. But it also remains firmly wedded to a pre-Internet technology — the fax machine — that in most other developed nations has joined answering machines, eight-tracks and cassette tapes in the dustbin of outmoded technologies.

articles.headline: Obama Bid for Europe Trade Pact Stirs Hope on Both Sides
articles.snippet: Tough economic times and a perceived need to unify Europe’s frayed union — and the growing economic might of China — could help a free-trade agreement succeed now, experts said.
articles.abstract: Tough economic times and a perceived need to unify Europe’s frayed union — and the growing economic might of China — could help a free-trade agreement succeed now, experts said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — President Obama’s call for a free-trade agreement between the United States and the European Union has unleashed a wave of optimism on both sides that a breakthrough can be achieved that would lift trans-Atlantic fortunes, not just economically but politically.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: A Workout Booster, and a Lawsuit
articles.snippet: A case involving the death of Michael L. Sparling, who used Jack3d supplements, highlights gaps in product safety of a $30 billion industry.
articles.abstract: A case involving the death of Michael L. Sparling, who used Jack3d supplements, highlights gaps in product safety of a $30 billion industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last few weeks, GNC, the dietary supplements retailer, has run a special on its Web site for a workout booster called Jack3d. “Hot Buy, Hot Buy, Hot Buy,” reads a red banner splashed across the product’s page.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: To Reduce Suicide Rates, New Focus Turns to Guns
articles.snippet: Despite the attention on mass shootings and assault weapons, far more Americans die by turning firearms on themselves.
articles.abstract: Despite the attention on mass shootings and assault weapons, far more Americans die by turning firearms on themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Wyo. — Craig Reichert found his son’s body on a winter morning, lying on the floor as if he were napping with his great-uncle’s pistol under his knee. The 911 dispatcher told him to administer CPR, but Mr. Reichert, who has had emergency training, told her it was too late. His son, Kameron, 17, was already cold to the touch.

articles.headline: Berkshire and 3G Capital in a $23 Billion Deal for Heinz
articles.snippet: Berkshire Hathaway, the giant conglomerate run by Warren E. Buffett, said on Thursday that it would buy the H. J. Heinz Company for about $23 billion. Berkshire is teaming up with 3G Capital, a Brazilian investment firm that already owns most of B...
articles.abstract: Berkshire Hathaway, the giant conglomerate run by Warren E. Buffett, said on Thursday that it would buy the H. J. Heinz Company for about $23 billion. Berkshire is teaming up with 3G Capital, a Brazilian investment firm that already owns most of Burger King.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin
